newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Fuel Oil-Firm with active bids, Indian demand.
newsitem.headline: Asia Fuel Oil-Firm with active bids, Indian demand.

text.p: The high sulphur fuel oil market was supported at firm levels on Tuesday with strong expectations that a big Singapore trading company would continue bidding up prices while India emerged for more April supplies, traders said.
Bids for the 180-cst grade for late April lifting were heard at $100/$101 per tonne while offers came down to $102 from an initial $103.
The 380-cst grade was heard bid/offered at $95/$96 per tonne.
On Monday, bids from the local trading company for the 180-cst grade moved around $100 per tonne but there were no suppliers.
"It's quite clear that the local trader wants to support the market because he started to bid," said one trader.
"Suppliers are hoping the local trader to continue bidding up so they are unwilling to sell now," he added.
Recent fuel oil purchase by Taiwan and India also inspired a more bullish sentiment, traders said.
India issued a tender to buy a 30,000-tonne cargo of 3.5-percent sulphur fuel oil for April 26-30 lifting, after already buying three cargoes for April lifting.
Traders said India's recent purchase was to meet seasonal demand in the summer time.
"Overall the demand side is quite healthy, so prices should continue going up, or at least well-supported," said one trader.
In the LSWR market, bids were heard at $17.30 per tonne but sentiment was bearish.
Indonesia's state oil company Pertamina has announced the loading schedule for its 3.6 million barrels of LSWR for lifting in April, lower than 3.7 million barrels in March.
However, traders were bearish amid weak regional demand and a surplus of barrels with some 400,000 to 500,000 barrels rolled over for lifting in April from March.
There was also about 1.0 million barrels of straight-run LSWR available from Singapore and Malaysia in April, they said.
(Prices in dollars per tonne, unless stated)
MTH FOB SIN BUY/SELL PREV BUY/SELL
*Dollars per barrel
--Singapore newsroom (+65-870 3571)
